quizTitle: O-Level Chemistry: Simple Cells & Hydrogen Fuel Cells
instructions: Answer all questions on simple electrochemical cells and hydrogen fuel cells. All questions test conceptual understanding only — no charge or mass calculations required.

questions.question: Why do different metal pairs produce different voltages in a simple cell?
options: Different metals have different densities
Different metals conduct electricity at different speeds
Different metals have different tendencies to lose electrons (reactivity)
The electrolyte reacts differently with each metal
questions.explanation: Voltage depends on the difference in tendency to lose electrons (reactivity). Larger difference (e.g., magnesium/copper) produces higher voltage than smaller difference (e.g., iron/copper).

questions.question: In a simple cell made of zinc and copper electrodes in dilute sulfuric acid, which electrode is the negative terminal?
options: Copper, because it gains electrons
Both are negative
Zinc, because it loses electrons more readily
Neither – simple cells have no polarity
questions.explanation: Zinc is more reactive than copper → loses electrons (Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻) → electrons flow OUT from zinc → zinc is the negative terminal. Copper is the positive terminal.

questions.question: How can you experimentally determine which of two unknown metals (X and Y) is more reactive using a simple cell?
options: Measure which metal has higher density
Add acid and see which produces more bubbles
Heat both metals and see which melts first
Connect them in a cell; the metal that becomes the negative terminal is more reactive
questions.explanation: In a simple cell, the more reactive metal loses electrons and becomes the negative terminal (anode). Observing which electrode is negative with a voltmeter reveals relative reactivity.

questions.question: What is the overall reaction in a hydrogen fuel cell?
options: H₂O → H₂ + ½O₂
2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O
O₂ + 4H⁺ + 4e⁻ → 2H₂O
questions.explanation: Overall reaction: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O. Hydrogen oxidizes at the anode, oxygen reduces at the cathode. The only chemical product is water.

questions.question: Which advantage does a hydrogen fuel cell have over a simple chemical cell (battery)?
options: It uses cheaper materials
It works without an electrolyte
It can be recharged by reversing current
It produces no harmful emissions – only water
questions.explanation: Hydrogen fuel cells produce only water as by-product (if H₂ is pure). Batteries may contain toxic metals (e.g., cadmium, lead) requiring special disposal. Fuel cells also operate continuously with fuel supply.

questions.question: In a magnesium/copper simple cell, magnesium is the negative terminal. What happens at the magnesium electrode?
options: No reaction – it only conducts electrons
Reduction: Mg²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Mg
Hydrogen gas is produced
Oxidation: Mg → Mg²⁺ + 2e⁻
questions.explanation: Negative terminal = anode = oxidation. Magnesium is more reactive → loses electrons: Mg → Mg²⁺ + 2e⁻. Electrons flow through the external circuit to the copper electrode.

questions.question: Why does a simple cell stop working after some time?
options: Electrons run out
The metals become magnetized
One electrode gets used up or reaction products block the surface
The voltage gradually decreases to zero without reason
questions.explanation: Simple cells stop because: (1) The reactive metal anode dissolves completely, OR (2) Hydrogen bubbles form on the cathode ('polarization'), blocking further reaction and stopping electron flow.

questions.question: Which statement about hydrogen fuel cells is TRUE?
options: They store energy chemically like batteries
They require recharging with electricity
They produce carbon dioxide as waste
They convert chemical energy directly to electrical energy continuously with fuel supply
questions.explanation: Fuel cells GENERATE electricity continuously as long as hydrogen and oxygen are supplied. Batteries STORE energy and deplete; fuel cells are energy converters, not storage devices.

questions.question: Three metals P, Q, R are tested in simple cells with copper. Results: P/Cu = 1.5 V (P negative), Q/Cu = 0.8 V (Q negative), R/Cu = 0.3 V (R negative). Which is the MOST reactive?
options: Copper
R
Q
P
questions.explanation: All three metals are more reactive than copper (all are negative terminals). Larger voltage = greater difference in reactivity from copper → P has the largest voltage difference → P is the most reactive metal.

questions.question: What is the key difference between a simple chemical cell and a hydrogen fuel cell?
options: Fuel cells produce AC current; simple cells produce DC
Simple cells need an electrolyte; fuel cells do not
Simple cells use metals; fuel cells use gases
Simple cells deplete as reactants are used up; fuel cells run continuously with fuel supply
questions.explanation: Simple cells (e.g., zinc/copper) stop when the metal anode dissolves or products accumulate. Hydrogen fuel cells keep producing electricity as long as hydrogen and oxygen are continuously supplied.

questions.question: In a simple cell with iron and silver electrodes in sodium chloride solution, which electrode corrodes (loses mass)?
options: Silver, because it is less dense
Neither corrodes in NaCl solution
Both corrode equally
Iron, because it is more reactive and oxidizes
questions.explanation: Iron is more reactive than silver → iron oxidizes (Fe → Fe²⁺ + 2e⁻) at the anode → loses mass. Silver acts as the cathode where reduction occurs (e.g., oxygen reduction) → does not corrode.

questions.question: Why is platinum used as electrodes in hydrogen fuel cells?
options: It produces extra voltage
It is cheap and abundant
It prevents water formation
It acts as a catalyst for hydrogen/oxygen reactions
questions.explanation: Platinum catalyzes the reactions: hydrogen oxidation at the anode and oxygen reduction at the cathode. Without this catalyst, the reactions would be too slow for practical electricity generation.

questions.question: Two simple cells are set up: Cell A uses magnesium and copper electrodes; Cell B uses zinc and copper electrodes. Which statement is TRUE?
options: Cell B has a higher voltage because zinc is closer to copper in the reactivity series
Both cells have the same voltage because copper is used in both
Cell A has a higher voltage because magnesium is much more reactive than zinc
Cell B has a higher voltage because zinc conducts electricity better
questions.explanation: Magnesium is much more reactive than zinc (higher in reactivity series). Magnesium/copper has a larger reactivity difference than zinc/copper → Cell A (Mg/Cu) produces a higher voltage than Cell B (Zn/Cu).

questions.question: What happens to the electrolyte in a simple cell with zinc and copper electrodes in dilute sulfuric acid?
options: It turns blue immediately
Its pH remains constant
It becomes more acidic as H⁺ ions are produced
It becomes less acidic as H⁺ ions are consumed at the copper cathode
questions.explanation: At the copper cathode: 2H⁺ + 2e⁻ → H₂(g). Hydrogen ions are consumed → concentration of H⁺ decreases → pH increases (solution becomes less acidic). At the zinc anode: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ (no H⁺ involved).

questions.question: Which environmental benefit do hydrogen fuel cells offer for vehicles?
options: They use less rubber for tires
They reduce noise pollution only
They work better in cold weather
They eliminate tailpipe emissions – only water vapour is released
questions.explanation: Fuel cell vehicles emit only water vapour from the tailpipe. (Note: Overall environmental benefit depends on how the hydrogen is produced – renewable sources give near-zero carbon footprint.)
